Headline: Important Moments in the History of LGBTQ+ Olympians
John Curry
Text: At the 1976 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, Austria, figure skater John Curry won a gold medal, making him the first openly LGBTQ+ Olympic Champion.

Headline: Georgia Simmerling
Text: At the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, Georgia Simmerling became the only LGBTQ+ Olympian to compete in three different sports.

Headline: Ireen Wüst
Text: At the 2018 Winter Olympics in PyeongChang, South Korea, Ireen Wüst won her eleventh medal, making her the most successful LGBTQ+ athlete of all time.

Headline: Mel Daluzyan
Text: Transgender athlete Mel Daluzyan was disqualified from the 2012 Winter Olympics because of drugs he had taken to begin his transition.

Headline: Robert Dover
Text: At the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, Robert Dover was the first male Olympian to compete openly as a member of the LGBTQ+ community.

Headline: Laurel Hubbard
Text: At the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, Laurel Hubbard became the first female indentifying transgender Olympian.

Headline: Ewa Klobukowska
Text: In 1968, Ewa Klobukowska became the first of many athletes to be barred from competing in the Olympics due to failing the IOC's gender test.

Headline: Miraildes “Formiga” Mota
Text: At the 2020 Summer Olympics, Miraildes Mota became the only LGBTQ+ athlete to have competed in seven different Olympic Games.

Headline: Tom Waddell
Text: In 1981, Olympian Tom Waddell founded the Gay Games that took place a year later in San Francisco, California.

Headline: Quinn
Text: After winning a bronze medal in the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Quinn became the first transgender medalist.

Headline: Fanny “Bobbie” Rosenfeld
Text: At the 1928 Summer Olympics in Amsterdam, Netherlands, Fanny “Bobbie” Rosenfeld became the first female LGBTQ+ Olympian.

Headline: Leif Rovsing
Text: At the 1912 Summer Olympics in Stockholm, Sweden, Leif Rovsing became the first male LGBTQ+ Olympian.

Headline: Edinanci Silva
Text: At the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, Georgia, Edinanci Silva became the first intersex athlete to be accepted into the women's competition.
